newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.

text.p: Spanish government bonds, after a soft opening, ended higher on Thursday tracking closely other foreign markets, especially the German Bunds.
"These days the Spanish market is just mimicking the German one, but it's still very strong and bids remain high both from here and from outside," a dealer said.
Trading volume was also considered high.

The 10-year spread over Bunds ended virtually unchanged from yesterday after it moved in an intra-day range between 98 and 100 basis points. And dealers were ruling out any autonomous movement before the December CPI, due next Wednesday (15/1).
After November CPI was unchanged in the month and up 3.2 percent year-on-year versus 3.5 percent in October, dealers expectations are very positive on further declines.

"But December CPI could come out against this general downtrend...we had an increase in tobacco prices," a dealer said, adding that he still expects Spanish inflation to be reined in soon to below the three percent level.
The shorter part of the yield curve is attracting good demand, with dealers expecting further steepening in the short term.
